rules: Rule1: Either the artist has a license for the artwork or the artwork is in the public domain.

Rule2: Provided that automated screening is enabled on the platform, either the artwork has a virus scan or, if the artist has a license for the artwork, then the artwork is approved for the platform.
Rule3: Whenever manual screening is required for the artwork, automated screening is bypassed for the artwork.
Rule4: In the event that manual screening is required for the artwork, it is not the case that automated screening is bypassed for the artwork.
Rule5: Should the artwork be in the public domain, then it is approved for the platform.
Rule6: If the artwork is flagged as suspicious, then it has a virus scan.
Rule7: Either the artwork is flagged as suspicious or a manual review of the artwork is complete.
Rule8: Whenever a manual review of the artwork is complete, the curator approved the artwork.
Rule9: If the curator approved the artwork, then it passed the technical check.
Rule10: Should the curator approve the artwork, then it passed the aesthetic review.
Rule11: In the case that the artwork passed the technical check, if the artist has a license for the artwork, then the artwork is approved for the platform.
Rule12: If the artist submitted an appeal, then the appeal was granted to the artist.
Rule13: Whenever the artist submits an appeal, it is not the case that the appeal is granted to the artist.

Rule14: If it is not the case that, when the artwork passed the aesthetic review, then if the artist has a license for the artwork, the artwork is approved for the platform, then the artist submitted an appeal.
Rule15: In the event that automated screening is not enabled on the platform, manual screening is required for the artwork.
facts: Fact1: The artwork does not have a virus scan.

question: The artwork is approved for the platform.
